admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the East Java Bali Urban
            Development Project in Indonesia were as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, project
            sustainability was uncertain, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were rated satisfactory. Lessons
            learned includes: 1) East Java Bali (EJB) made a signal
            contribution in operational zing the decentralization
            objectives of Government of Indonesia (GOI's) urban
            policy statement. The Integrated Urban Infrastructure
            Development Programming (IUIDP) approach was a major
            departure from earlier sectoral approaches to addressing
            urban infrastructure services. It recognized that urban
            management is necessarily multi-sectoral and complex, and
            attempted to get urban managers to prepare Medium-Term (five
            years) Investment Program (PJMs) for urban infrastructure
            sectors by allocating the available limited resources
            optimally between sectors. In practice, while integrated
            planning made a good start at the global level, at the
            detail level planning remained sectoral; and 2) water supply
            presents an interesting special case. Now that the
            decentralization of investment programs from Cipta Karya to
            the Local Government Water Enterprise (PDAMs) has largely
            been achieved through EJB, it is time to focus on the major
            reform agenda for the sector to improve service delivery -
            institutional changes, financing options, private sector
            participation outlined in the 1997 Bank paper and adopted by GOI.
